title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
3 points maximum

Description Point: 1 point for any description listed for either renewable or nonrenewable

Example Points: 1 point for a renewable example and 1 point for a nonrenewable example

Description:


Renewable resources:

Normally replenished by natural processes

NOT depleted by moderate use.

Essentially inexhaustible on a human time scale


Nonrenewable resources:

NOT replenished by natural processes within a useful time scale

Depleted by use

Exists in a fixed amount and is exhaustible

Examples of Renewable resources:

  • Energy

  • Tidal

  • Solar

  • Wind

  • Geothermal

  • Hydroelectric

  • Biomass: wood, CH4 from waste, etc.

  • Biological

  • Trees

  • Organisms: (specify type)

  • Soil/Topsoil

  • Chemical

  • H2O

  • O2

  • CO2

  • N2

  • H2

  • Soil/Topsoil Etc.

Examples of Nonrenewable resources:

  • Energy

  • Fossil fuels: oil, coal, natural gas

  • Uranium

  • Oil Shale

  • Metals

  • Iron

  • Copper

  • Aluminum

  • Gold

  • Silver

  • Platinum

  • Zinc

  • Etc.

  • Nonmetals

  • Clay

  • Limestone

  • Sand

  • Gravel

  • Salt

  • Phosphates

  • Etc.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
3 points maximum

Comparison (1 point) : The two types of countries are not similar because the total resource use per capita is much greater in developed countries than in developing countries (the specific phrase "per capita" does not need to be used; however, it must be stated that the use being discussed is for an individual, or average individual, not an aggregate population).


Description (2 points): 1 point for each choice, up to 2 points
descriptions:
Student response earns none of the available points.

3 points maximum

Comparison (1 point) : The two types of countries are not similar because the total resource use per capita is much greater in developed countries than in developing countries (the specific phrase "per capita" does not need to be used; however, it must be stated that the use being discussed is for an individual, or average individual, not an aggregate population).

Description (2 points): 1 point for each choice, up to 2 points

The student response earns one of the following points:


Comparison (1 point):

The two types of countries are not similar because the total resource use per capita is much greater in developed countries than in developing countries (the specific phrase "per capita" does not need to be used; however, it must be stated that the use being discussed is for an individual, or average individual, not an aggregate population).

Description (2 points): 1 point for each choice, up to 2 points

The student response earns two of the following points:

Comparison (1 point):

The two types of countries are not similar because the total resource use per capita is much greater in developed countries than in developing countries (the specific phrase "per capita" does not need to be used; however, it must be stated that the use being discussed is for an individual, or average individual, not an aggregate population).

Description (2 points): 1 point for each choice, up to 2 points

The student response earns three of the following points:


Comparison (1 point):

The two types of countries are not similar because the total resource use per capita is much greater in developed countries than in developing countries (the specific phrase "per capita" does not need to be used; however, it must be stated that the use being discussed is for an individual, or average individual, not an aggregate population).

Description (2 points): 1 point for each choice, up to 2 points

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
3 points maximum

Definition (1 point) : the use of a resource at a rate that does not reduce its availability or its ability to be replenished on a long-term basis.

Examples (2 points) : the concept of sustainable resource USE must be indicated as opposed to just listing a sustainable resource (explain how its usage is sustainable)

  • 1 point for the sustainable resource and use

  • 1 point for elaboration (i.e., explain technical terms such as contour plowing, etc.)

  • Sustainable Resource: Timber

    Use: harvest of timber not to exceed regeneration rate

    Possible Elaboration/Explanation: discussion of forestry practices

  • Sustainable Resource: Water

    Use:

  • groundwater usage not to exceed recharge rate

  • utilization of sewage, drinking water, or desalination treatment processes to restore water

    quality at a rate which replenishes the water supply required for use

  • Use of reclaimed water, gray water, or nonpotable water for irrigation

    • Possible Elaboration/Explanation:

  • water conservation or specific pollution control measures

  • water conservation or specific pollution control measures (i.e. improving tertiary

    treatment)

  • source of such water is from bathtubs, showers, bathroom sinks, clothes washers, sewage

    treatment plants, etc.

  • Sustainable Resource: Soil/Topsoil

    Use : use regeneration farming techniques (such as contour plowing, strip farming,intercropping, terracing, reduced tillage, cover crops, etc.) to reduce topsoil disturbance and erosion

    Possible Elaboration/Explanation: explain technique

  • Sustainable Resource: Extractive Reserves

    Use : the harvest of nonwood products such as nuts, fruits, and rubber by local residents as a way to prevent deforestation

    Possible Elaboration/Explanation: by providing an alternative cash crop

  • Sustainable Resource: Fish

    Use: harvest must leave enough breeding stock to renew the species

    Possible Elaboration/Explanation:

    techniques: annual quotas, limit fishing seasons, regulate type of fishing gear, etc.

  • Sustainable Resource: Energy

    Use: explain how the substitution of a specific renewable energy resource for a specific

    non renewable energy resource leads toward sustainability

    Possible Elaboration/Explanation: discussion of issues involved with making this transition

  • Sustainable Resource: Rangeland

    Use: use selective grazing to allow grasses to regrow.

    Possible Elaboration/Explanation: discuss connection between desertification and overgrazing

  • Sustainable Resource: Reuse and Recycling

    Use: the use and reuse of metals (such as aluminum), glass, plastics, etc. in a way that leads toward sustainability

    Possible Elaboration/Explanation:

  • closed-loop vs. open-loop recycling

  • recycling reduces the mining of virgin resources

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
3 points maximum

Students must include 1 facilitating policy (1 point) and ONE impeding policy (1 point). The policies CANNOT be mere opposites of each other. (1 point) is available for a detailed discussion of the economic policy and how it can be implemented and affect use.
descriptions:

Student response earns one of the available points.
